The constitution states 
 
 "We the people of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, provide for the common defense, promote the general welfare, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity, do ordain and establish this Constitution for the United States of America."

Also, millions more unwanted children mean more crime and poverty. Which is not good for society and is not upholding the constitution. We have way too many kids no one gives a XXXX about, why must we need more? It would also be illogical to presume that the fetus is a person. The defonition of a person is:
 
 per·son Listen: [ pûrsn ]
 n. 
 
 The living body of a human: searched the prisoner's person. 
 
 A human or organization with legal rights and duties.
 
 The composite of characteristics that make up an individual personality; the self. 
 
 Christianity Any of the three separate individualities of the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, as distinguished from the essence of the Godhead that unites them. 
 
 A living human. Often used in combination: chairperson; spokesperson; salesperson. 
 
 
 Obviously, none of these fits a fetus or embryo. The pro life position fails to take into account the rest of society, that we would be overpopulated over abortion criminalization. Crime will rise, taxes will rise to pay for the welfare of the homesless, and we will be one step closer to an overpopulated society. 6 billion is enough, we don't need any more.
Rekhyt2238

and are only trying to earn themselves brownie points in heavan.
 

 
 And you are only trying to earn yourself brownie points in hell.
thelmoose

We should all agree that there either is such a thing or there isn't. Many on the prolife side believe there is. Many on the prochoice side believe there is not.
 
 Many (if not the majority) prochoice people do not believe in the inherent dignity of women and therefore trivialize them by not acknowledging that they have more inherent value than plants, animals, and dust. It does not surprise me that these same individuals argue that the fetus (a smaller, less developed, dependent human) does not have any inherent value or worth. Yet it is quite strange that they would argue against infanticide, as if all of a sudden because the fetus starts breathing oxygen in a different way than it did 2 seconds before means that it has an "inherent value" that they don't even believe in. Ironic.
 
 Yet, is it not ironic that these same individuals will lash out and say that the prolife person is trivializing the lives of millions of women. It may be true that some prolifers do, but i would argue that they are not truly pro life. The pro life position says that human beings have inherent dignity and worth and not only pay the lipservice to this but walk out this belief.
 
 How can the pro choice argument based on this empty perspective have any credibility in this discussion if it denies that human beings have an inherent dignity and worth that distinguishes them from plants and animals. Isn't the idea of rights based on the idea that people are deserving of those rights because they have inherent value?
 
 Where is the logic in saying that women are not inherently worth more than a whale, but they are inherently more valuable than a fetus who in two seconds will become a "person".
 
 Thanks for commenting Tastyfish. I am not trying to bash you here, but instead trying to make a point about the prochoice position.

 
 Correct me if I am wrong, Chloe, but this is what I gather is your argument:
 
 1. Human beings have "inherent value" and that value is relatively greater than other animals, plants or inanimate things. 
 
 2. Fetuses also have "inherent value" equal to other humans.
 
 3. Secular humanists or pro-choice proponents or whatever label to brand us, disagree with that and don't think humans and fetuses have this "inherent value."
 
 Am I right so far?
 
 What is this "inherent value" of which you speak. I think that phrase might be an oxymoron. If the value is inherent, then what does it matter what others think? Value is by definition a relative term. Are you saying that pro-choice people value humanity less than pro-lifers? Because that statement, on the whole, is decidely not true. 
 
 You have these pat little phrases that are all cute and all, but I think you need to examine these words. 
 
 I do not believe in god (a better description, I think, than calling me secular) and I believe it should remain legal for a women to have an abortion. 
 
 I still am quite capable to assign immense value to humanity and I do. In some circumstances I think the place humans in a superior positon to animals. I believe murdering humans is wrong, but I eat meat. I still think animals deserve to be protected and the animal kingdom is a wondrous and beautiful thing to behold. I do not think abortion is murder. I think the condition and welfare of the mother outweighs that of the fetus. It is really that simple.
 
 You have to consider the possibility of assiging relative value based on context and careful consideration.
Rekhyt2238

I do not believe in god (a better description, I think, than calling me secular) and I believe it should remain legal for a women to have an abortion.

 
 Then what do you believe happens to the souls of the fetuses that are murdered? You can't use the argument that god gives the soul at the time of birth just as he takes it away at death, because you don't believe in a god.
thelmoose

Then what do you believe happens to the souls of the fetuses that are murdered? You can't use the argument that god gives the soul at the time of birth just as he takes it away at death, because you don't believe in a god.

Ok, change soul to: Life-force, spirit, or whatever-the-hell-gives-us-life. What happens to it then? Does that person just never get to live?
thelmoose

Ok, change soul to: Life-force, spirit, or whatever-the-hell-gives-us-life. What happens to it then? Does that person just never get to live?

There are lots of living things, none of which have souls, or life-forces or whatever, because those things don't exist. There is nothing outside of biology that "gives us life" or gives life to anything else. Living things are simply alive. If you want to debate the definition of life, that's another can of worms. 
 
 Again, what point are you trying to make?
jitobear

Chloe I responded quite some back. This woman does not feel trivialized be being granted the right to choose.
 
 Stop stereotyping those who are pro-choice because they did not wish to respond to this thread - which had a pretty obvious agenda. I saw immediately that you would reach the conclusion that you did.

And you are only trying to earn yourself brownie points in hell.

 
 Actually, you're the one who's gonna end up in hell for devaluing and discriminating against women.

Shooterandproud

Then what do you believe happens to the souls of the fetuses that are murdered? You can't use the argument that god gives the soul at the time of birth just as he takes it away at death, because you don't believe in a god.

 
 Fetuses don't have souls. They are not human beings yet, they don't talk, they don't walk, they don't feel, and they dont even look remotely like humans. They look more like frogs.
chloe

My fingernail can be considered a smaller, less developed human...
 
 We don't know squat about inherit value...
 
 Like i said before, we don't know squat about value...
 
 We don't know anything about humans...
 

 
 Humans have inherent value and dignity.
 
 

 If the value is inherent, then what does it matter what others think? Value is by definition a relative term. Are you saying that pro-choice people value humanity less than pro-lifers? Because that statement, on the whole, is decidely not true. 
 
 
 I still am quite capable to assign immense value to humanity and I do. In some circumstances I think the place humans in a superior positon to animals. 

 
 
 It doesn't matter how many would tell you that you are not worth more than dirt, the truth is you are worth something and an inherent have value. 
 
 However, according to those who disregard this inherent value, a person's value is based on another's opinion. All the "people" with all the power get to decide who has value. That is elitist and depressing. If there is a room filled with people, and half the room says bill is valuable but the other half says he is not, is he inherently valuable or not? Can the pro choice position answer this question. 
 
 If you do not acknowledge that women have inherent value, you say that nothing distinguishes them from plants and animals. What a trivialization of the lives of millions of women.
Rekhyt2238

There is nothing more than our corporeal existence. The fetus (which is not a person, by the way) is living tissue. There are lots of living things, none of which have souls, or life-forces or whatever, because those things don't exist. There is nothing outside of biology that "gives us life" or gives life to anything else. Living things are simply alive. If you want to debate the definition of life, that's another can of worms. 
 
 Again, what point are you trying to make?

 
 If we don't have a soul, or whatever you want to call it, then how are we so much more civilized and advanced than animals?
Rekhyt2238

Actually, you're the one who's gonna end up in hell for devaluing and discriminating against women.

 
 Well then you're gonna end up right there next to me for discriminating/killing fetus's.
 
 
Fetuses don't have souls.

 
 And you know this how? Do you know for a fact that fetus's, or even zygote's for that matter, don't have souls?
thelmoose

Humans have inherent value and dignity. 

 OK. OK. Is anyone saying we have no value?
 You need to look up the word "inherent"
 
 
 
 
 It doesn't matter how many would tell you that you are not worth more than dirt, the truth is you are worth something and an inherent have value. 
 

 Stop it. No one has said anything about humans and dirt. You keep repeating the same phrases. You are not listening. You are behaving as though you don't really have any original ideas, such that you cannot respond to the questions put to you. 
 
 
 
 However, according to those who disregard this inherent value, a person's value is based on another's opinion. All the "people" with all the power get to decide who has value. That is elitist and depressing. If there is a room filled with people, and half the room says bill is valuable but the other half says he is not, is he inherently valuable or not? Can the pro choice position answer this question. 
 

 What are you talking about?
 And please leave poor Bill out of this, whoever he is.
 
 
 
 
 If you do not acknowledge that women have inherent value, you say that nothing distinguishes them from plants and animals. What a trivialization of the lives of millions of women. 

 
 Has anyone said this?
 Is this what you learn in home schooling?
thelmoose

If we don't have a soul, or whatever you want to call it, then how are we so much more civilized and advanced than animals?

 
 I don't want to call it anything as there is no such thing.
 
 Everyone knows that we are more civilized and advanced than animals because we have learned proper table manners and that it is important to promptly write thank you notes.
simone
Arghhh! Thelmooose! Why did you have to say that? My table manners are atrocious and, as for writing thank you notes promptly, argghhhh! Must I now be relegated to the realm of the beasts?

Shooterandproud

Humans have inherent value and dignity.

 
 We don't know that. You can't back that up can you?
 
 
 
 
 It doesn't matter how many would tell you that you are not worth more than dirt, the truth is you are worth something and an inherent have value.[/quote]
 
 There is no truth in that. Stop trying to make it look like this "inherit value" is a fact. Its not, its just a weird hypothesis of yours and has not been proven. 
 
 
However, according to those who disregard this inherent value, a person's value is based on another's opinion. All the "people" with all the power get to decide who has value.

 
 You mean the people with power decides who to treat better and who not to?
 
 
That is elitist and depressing. If there is a room filled with people, and half the room says bill is valuable but the other half says he is not, is he inherently valuable or not?

 
 Lets just assume this value exists. The value would be based on feeling and consciousness. We as people have consciousness and feelings, not to mencion we feel pain. Fetuses do not, therefore we cannot associate this much "value" to fetuses as we do humans. Its not elitist, its just life. Deal with it.
 
 
Can the pro choice position answer this question.

 
 Thats not the question. The question is, can the pro-life opinion answer this question? The pro lifers are risking women's health and well-being for an unproven "value" hypothesis that just might exist.
 
 
If you do not acknowledge that women have inherent value, you say that nothing distinguishes them from plants and animals. What a trivialization of the lives of millions of women.

 
 We don't know if women have any more value than plants. We do know that woman have consciousness, feel pain, and have real feelings. Plants do not, fetuses do not, therefore their needs must be regarded over the fetuses. A fetus can not make a descision, but the mother can. Therefore, we should leave it up to the mother to make the descision for her and her fetus, because she knows her circumstances best. You do not, the government does not, I do not.
Shooterandproud

If we don't have a soul, or whatever you want to call it, then how are we so much more civilized and advanced than animals?

 
 Starts with an E, ends with an N. I'll give you a hint, religious zealots are too ignorant to believe in it.
Shooterandproud

Well then you're gonna end up right there next to me for discriminating/killing fetus's.

 
 How do we know that fetuses are worth any more than ants? God has not said anything on this matter.
 
 
 
 
And you know this how? Do you know for a fact that fetus's, or even zygote's for that matter, don't have souls?

 
 I anyone does have a soul, I would think it would be a living, breathing human. One who has feelings, and consciousness, and free will, as God has said. Not a hunk of flesh inside of a woman's stomach.
Tastyfish

We should all agree that there either is such a thing or there isn't. Many on the prolife side believe there is. Many on the prochoice side believe there is not. 
 
 I sort of agree with you here, but I think its probably not quite so split down those lines. The majority of people who don't believe in them are probably pro-choice but I would guess that most people (at least in the US) do believe regardless of whose line they fall on.
 

 Many (if not the majority) prochoice people do not believe in the inherent dignity of women and therefore trivialize them by not acknowledging that they have more inherent value than plants, animals, and dust. It does not surprise me that these same individuals argue that the fetus (a smaller, less developed, dependent human) does not have any inherent value or worth. Yet it is quite strange that they would argue against infanticide, as if all of a sudden because the fetus starts breathing oxygen in a different way than it did 2 seconds before means that it has an "inherent value" that they don't even believe in. Ironic. 

 I don't think many people would really fall in the camp that a woman has no inherent value but a fetus/child does. Its more that value doesn't exist as an abstract concept but instead its a measure of something's worth to someone else. Just because I don't think a woman has more value than a plant or so because of some ethereal inherent value, doesn't mean I think women are worthless - to me it seems that the woman is worth more than the plant in the traditional meaning of the word. I believe there is a reason that women and everyone else should be valued rather than it just being some property of the label 'woman'.
 

 Yet, is it not ironic that these same individuals will lash out and say that the prolife person is trivializing the lives of millions of women. It may be true that some prolifers do, but i would argue that they are not truly pro life. The pro life position says that human beings have inherent dignity and worth and not only pay the lipservice to this but walk out this belief.
 If you look at the reasons why we think women have value, then the reason for the lashing out becomes clear - if you don't believe that there is some constant value of a person regardless of their condition, then by forcing a pregnancy on them you are making them less important. If we value the ability to choose and determine our own lives, then by removing some of that you are reducing the overall worth of our lives. To pick a pretty extreme example, its similar to how someone suffering from an incurable medical condition might find their quality of life so low its not worth living.
 

 How can the pro choice argument based on this empty perspective have any credibility in this discussion if it denies that human beings have an inherent dignity and worth that distinguishes them from plants and animals. Isn't the idea of rights based on the idea that people are deserving of those rights because they have inherent value?
 Its actually you who is saying here that there is no difference between people and plants - I'm saying that the differences in value exist due to the differences between the two, rather than the only thing adding value to a person is some ethereal quality that can't be described. This is the important point to consider regarding the two points of view.
 

 Where is the logic in saying that women are not inherently worth more than a whale, but they are inherently more valuable than a fetus who in two seconds will become a "person".
 
 I value intelligence and a mind, as well as not suffering, as three of the most important things there are (their value stems originally from what I am willing to tolerate being done to me more or less). There is a ton of additional things that I think are important, and some of these apply to whales but more apply to women. Some properties that whales and women have in common are not found in a fetus (or at least an early one) and so I don't think a fetus is as important as a woman or a whale.
JPSartre12

The conversation has often been focused on if the fetus is a person and if the fetus has inherent value.
 
 
 What about the mother? 
 
 Is the mother a person and does she have inherent value? Why or why not?

 All innocent people, born and unborn have inherent value.
Tastyfish

All innocent people, born and unborn have inherent value.

 
 Surely if they can lose that value though (with loss of innocence) its not actually inherent though. 
 
 Thats before we even get to defining innocence as well, I don't see how you can apply that term to an embryo and have it actually mean something. Though that said, defining innocence is easier said than done (an absence of sin or ability to do 'bad things')
JPSartre12

Surely if they can lose that value though (with loss of innocence) its not actually inherent though. 

 Good point. oor choice of words on my part. 
 

 Thats before we even get to defining innocence as well, I don't see how you can apply that term to an embryo and have it actually mean something. Though that said, defining innocence is easier said than done (an absence of sin or ability to do 'bad things')

 I'd define innocence as the absence of guilt. emoticon_xgood
Tastyfish

Surely its the absence of guilt in something capable of generating it though, otherwise we've got plants and rocks in it as well (plus psychopathic serial killers - rare contenders for the innocent title). However in that case then the Embryo is not going to count for the same reasons physiologically similar things don't count

However in that case then the Embryo is not going to count for the same reasons physiologically similar things don't count

Shooterandproud

I was thinking more in terms of murderers, you know, serious guilt. Everyone has some level of guilt but only a few deserver to die because of it.

 
 
 And who decides that?
Tastyfish

I was thinking more in terms of murderers, you know, serious guilt. Everyone has some level of guilt but only a few deserver to die because of it.

 But the very worst of the serial killers are the ones who don't feel empathy and have no conscience, thus they don't feel guilty for what they have done and might only consider it bad because they are aware that others do.
 
 Isn't a feeling of guilt an indication that they are sorry for what they have done as well? I'd still be worried more about the ones who didn't feel particularly guilty.
JPSartre12

But the very worst of the serial killers are the ones who don't feel empathy and have no conscience, thus they don't feel guilty for what they have done and might only consider it bad because they are aware that others do.
 
 Isn't a feeling of guilt an indication that they are sorry for what they have done as well? I'd still be worried more about the ones who didn't feel particularly guilty.

 
 I wasn't talking about their perception of guilt. I was speaking about their actual guilt of heinous crimes.

And who decides that?

 
 A jury of their peers.
Tastyfish

I wasn't talking about their perception of guilt. I was speaking about their actual guilt of heinous crimes.

 
 Fair enough, I was going to say something about that but didn't want to make yet another langauge point (English really is awful for this sort of thing).
 
 You've still not addressed the issue that surely the ability to commit heinous crimes is required to actually be innocent in some way, unless 'innocence' isn't actually the issue here at all.
Shooterandproud

A jury of their peers.

 
 No, not in terms of punishment. I mean who decides what is wrong and what is right in the long run? God? We may have different preceptions of what is guilty and what is not. Im just saying, that something that you think is guilt may not be.
